[LEXICON]: Overly formal, archaic vocabulary (e.g., "pre-eminence," "tesselated") and excessively complex sentence structures.
[SYNTAX]: Long, convoluted sentence structures (e.g., "The Romans...") that impair readability.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from Roman to Saxon period without clear bridging.
[CLARITY]: Assumes historical context (e.g., Ethelbert’s reign) without explanation.

[SYNTAX]: Abrupt, disconnected sentence ("A tablet lit up on the table.")
Overly complex sentence structures (e.g., lengthy clauses)

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transition from Christianization to St. Martin's church debate
[LOGIC]: Tangential comment about England’s 9-century shift from Papal authority
